name: GJ 433
scenarioDescription:
The GJ 433 Exoplanetary System

GJ 433 is a star with 0.48 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.5799999999999998 times its radius. It is located 29.58 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 433 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

GJ 433 b

GJ 433 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2013-01. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.37 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, GJ 433.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.04, which means that when GJ 433 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.06 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.06. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of GJ 433 b is 6.04 times the mass of Earth. At 6.04 Earth masses, GJ 433 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

GJ 433 c

GJ 433 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-06. Its semi-major axis is 4.82 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5094.10 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, GJ 433.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.12, which means that when GJ 433 c is at is at its closest point to its host star, 4.24 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 5.40. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of GJ 433 c is 32.42 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 433 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

GJ 433 d

GJ 433 d was discovered by the Multiple Facilities observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2020-01. Its semi-major axis is 0.18 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 36.06 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, GJ 433.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.07, which means that when GJ 433 d is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.17 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.19. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of GJ 433 d is 5.22 times the mass of Earth. At 5.22 Earth masses, GJ 433 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

With a semi-major axis of 0.178 astronomical units, and a mass of 5.22 Earth masses, GJ 433 d could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 433, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by La Silla Observatory.
